title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
Assignment 4:
Given a set of Data:


For each variable, compute expected value, variance and standard deviation.

Explain, if it makes sense to compare the standard deviations.

Then, examine the relationship between both variables and compute the covariance and correlation

What measure is easier to interpret? Please discuss your interpretation.

Compute the conditional expected value for:

\(E[income|age<=18]\)

\(E[income|age \in [18,65)]\)

\(E[income|age>=65]\)



Solution:

Code & results:


#Loading Libraries & files:
library(tidyverse)
random_vars <- readRDS("D:/OneDrive/Samantha/TUHH/1stsemester/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics (SE)/Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")
#Viewing the Data:
random_vars



  


#Calculating the Expected Values:
expectedValues <-summarize(random_vars, Age_Expected_Value=mean(age, na.rm = TRUE), Income_Expected_Value=mean(income, na.rm = TRUE))
expectedValues



  


#Calculating the Variance:
variances <-summarize(random_vars, Age_Variance=var(age, na.rm = TRUE), Income_Variance=var(income, na.rm = TRUE))
variances



  


#Calculating the Standard Deviation:
std <-summarize(random_vars, Age_Standard_Deviation=sd(age, na.rm = TRUE), Income_Standard_Deviation=sd(income, na.rm = TRUE))
std



  




The standard deviation is a measure of the proportions of the data being far away from the expected value, therefore, in this case the values stand for age and income and the comparison won’t indicate anything.
Code & results:


#Relationships Between Variables:
cov_corr <-summarize(random_vars, Covariance=cov(age,income), Correlation=cor(age,income))
cov_corr



  




The covariance is the relationship between the two variables and hoe they behave to each other (Measure of linear dependency). Therefore when the value is a high positive value, it means that the two variables are moving into the same direction. But it is not possible to indicate whether the result is high or not as there is no value to compare relative to it. Therefore, using the correlation value is better as the correlation is the standardized measure and is by construction bounded between -1 and 1. The high values in magnitude (close to 1 or -1) indicates very strong linear relationship and the direction of this relation is represented by the algebraic sign.







Note



Interpretation: Since both values of the covariance and correlation are positive, the age and income are moving in the same direction. And using the correlation value which is 0.548, this means that relation falls in the beginning of the of the strong range of correlation.
(According to https://www.tastylive.com/concepts-strategies/correlation#:~:text=Positive%20correlation%20is%20measured%20on,move%20in%20the%20same%20direction. Positive correlation is measured on a 0.1 to 1.0 scale. Weak positive correlation would be in the range of 0.1 to 0.3, moderate positive correlation from 0.3 to 0.5, and strong positive correlation from 0.5 to 1.0).
This means that when the age increases, the income increases and vice versa (not with the same exact rate).



The conditional expected values:


\(E[income|age<=18]\):


#The expected value of the income when age<=18:
condExpectedValue1<-mean(filter(random_vars,age<=18)$income)
condExpectedValue1

#> [1] 389.6074



\(E[income|age\in[18,65)]\)


#The expected value of the income when 18<=age<65:
condExpectedValue2<-mean(filter(random_vars,18<=age & age<65)$income)
condExpectedValue2

#> [1] 4685.734



\(E[income|age>=65]\)


#The expected value of the income when age>=65:
condExpectedValue3<-mean(filter(random_vars,age>=65)$income)
condExpectedValue3

#> [1] 1777.237

title: Probability Theory
text:
1 Basic Rules of Probability

If \(A\) is an event –> \(\overline{A}\) is the complement
with \(P(A)+P(\overline{A})=1\)
Impossible Event: \(P(A)=0\), Certain Event: \(P(A)=1\)
Probability is a real number greater or equal to 0
Total probability is equal to 1
\(\cup\) : Union/ or , \(\cap\) : Intersection/ and
Non-Mutually Exclusive: \(P(A \cup B)= P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B)\) –> Addition Rule




Venn Diagram of Non-Mutually Exclusive Events



Mutually Exclusive: \(P(A \cup B)= P(A) + P(B)\) as the events can’t happen at the same time \(P(A \cap B)=0\)




Venn Diagram of Mutually Exclusive Events



Conditional Probability:
\(P(A|B)\) is the probability of \(A\) happening given that \(B\) has happened
If \(A , B\) are independent: \(P(A|B)= P(A)\) –> Stochastic Independent
\(P(A \cap B)= P(A|B) * P(B)= P(B|A) * P(A)\)
then \(P(A|B)= \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)}\) –> Multiplication Rule



2 Probability Tree

Branches from 1 Node sum to 1
Probability of two consecutive events is obtained by multiplying the probabilities


Assignment 1:
Given the following Probability Tree and with defining being on time as event \(T\), being not on time as \(\overline{T}\), having a change in scope as \(S\) and having no change in scope as \(\overline{S}\)







Solution:
\(P(T\cap S)= 0.3* 0.2=0.6\)
\(P(T\cap \overline{S})= 0.7* 0.6=0.42\)
\(P(\overline{T}\cap S)= 0.3* 0.8=0.24\)
\(P(\overline{T}\cap \overline{S})= 0.7* 0.4=0.28\)



3 Set Theory

Venn Diagrams are used to visualize the occurrence & relationships between events




Generic Venn Diagram



Assignment 2:
Using a random sample of 1000 cistomers of application development company that has developed an app available on either Smartphones “\(S\)”, Tablets “\(T\)” or Computers “\(C\)”. Given the Venn Diagram of the number of customers using each device.







Solution:

The percentage of customers using all three devices: \(P(S\cap T\cap C)=0.5\%\)
The percentage of customers using at least two devices: \(P(S\cap T) + P(T\cap C) + P(C\cap S)+ P(S\cap T\cap C)=7.3+3.3+8.8+0.5=19.9\%\)
The percentage of customers using only one device: \(= 42.3 + 27.8+ 10=80.1\%\)
or \(100 - P\)(at least 2 devices)\(= 100-19.9=80.1\%\)




4 Bayes Theorem
\(P(A|B)= \frac{P(A|B)*P(A)}{P(B)}= \frac{P(A|B)*P(A)}{P(B|A)*P(A)+P(B|\overline{A})*P(\overline{A})}\) –> Bayesian Rule

Assignment 3:
You are quality assurance manager and you want to buy a new tool that automates part of the quality assurance. If the tool finds a product it considers faulty, an alarm is triggered. The seller of the tool states that if a product is faulty, the tool is 97% reliable and if the product is flawless, the test is 99% reliable. Also, from your past experience you know that 4% of your products come out with flaws.


Givens:
\(P(B|A)=0.97\)
\(P(B|\overline{A})=0.01\)
\(P(\overline{B}|\overline{A})=0.99\)
\(P(A)=0.04\)
\(P(\overline{A})=0.96\)


Solution:
Using the Bayesian Rule:

\(P(\overline{A}|B)=\frac{0.01*0.96}{(0.01*0.96)+(0.97*0.04)}= 0.1983471074 =19.83\%\)
\(P(A|B)=\frac{0.97*0.04}{(0.01*0.96)+(0.97*0.04)}= 0.8016528926 =80.17\%\)
Verification: \(P(\overline{A}|B)+P(A|B)=19.83+80.17=100\%\)

These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about 19.83% that the product is flawless and a probability of 80.17% that the product is faulty.
